_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Butane tank, pressure relief valves, excess flow valves and pump

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1	The HWRT Terminal - Norris City, LLC (HWRT) facility is a terminal for the storage and distribution of various fuels.  Petroleum products (i.e., gasoline and diesel) are received by pipeline.  Transport trucks deliver ethanol and other additives to the facility.  Transport trucks deliver the products to the facility's customers.  HWRT has a 30,000 gallon butane storage tank and a butane injection process at the facility.  Butane has been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency as a regulated substance subject to 40 CFR Part 68, which required the preparation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  HWRT is also subject to the OSHA process safety management standard and is submitting a program level 3 Risk Management Plan.

The initial construction of the terminal facility was completed in 1960, and it included construction of Tanks NC-01 through NC-04.  HWRT Terminal - Norris City, LLC purchased the terminal from Crown Central Petroleum Corporation in 2004.

The facility is located on Cherry Street, approximately 0.5 mile west of U.S. Highway 1 and 0.25 mile north of Main Street in Norris City.  The immediate vicinity is sparsely populated; however, the closest residence is across the street from the facility's exit gate.  The facility has fuel and additive storage tanks with capacities ranging from 1000 to more than 2,500,000 gallons.  Each of these tanks is provided with adequate secondary containment.  

The butane injection process is fairly simple.  Liquefied butane gas is delivered in tank trucks and pumped into the butane tank.  Butane is stored under ambient temperatures which can exceed 100 degrees F in the summer.  Butane is injected into gasoline by pumping it into the pipeline as the gasoline is being delivered to an HWRT storage tank.  The butane injection can occur either from the butane storage tank or directly from the tank truck unloading butane.

2	It is HWRT's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulation

s.
The owners and management of this facility regard employee and public safety as a very serious matter and have taken many precautions to maintain a safe working and public environment.  Some of these precautions include:

Â¿	Preparing and implementing a Facility Response Plan (FRP);
Â¿	Complying with NFPA 58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code
Â¿	Annual inspections of the butane system by a qualified outside contractor;
Â¿	Preparing and implementing a Spill, Prevention, Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan;
Â¿	Instituting safe operating procedures;
Â¿	Training employees in safety programs and procedures; and
Â¿	Coordinating with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

3	General accidental release prevention program

Employees are trained to recognize the hazards of the process and all changes to the process are reviewed to ensure that the safety, health, and environmental consequences of the change are addressed prior to making the change.  This facility has a strong commitment to the safe handling of butane and other flammable materials and to minimizing the probability of an accidental release.  This is achieved through a combination of safety equipment, personnel training and operating procedures.  The safety equipment includes excess flow valves, pressure relief valves and emergency shut off valves.  The butane tank and supporting equipment was inspected, tested and refurbished in October, 2005 prior to initiating the butane process at this facility.

In addition, HWRT has contracted with an experienced, knowledgeable, outside contractor to perform annual inspections of the butane system.  This inspection includes evaluating the condition of the tank, piping, and supports, checking the internal valves, pressure relief valves, emergency shut-off valves and cables, pressure gauge, and liquid pump. 

4	Five-year accident history

This facility has not had a release of butane or other regulated substance as defined in 40 CFR 68.3 and 68.130 or an OSHA highly h

azardous chemical as defined in 40 CFR 29.1910(b).

5	Emergency response program

The facility emergency response programs include FRP and SPCC Plans.  The FRP includes information regarding emergency response, hazard identification, various discharge scenarios, descriptions of periodic drills and exercises and describes employee training.  The SPCC Plan includes similar information as well as facility inspection forms.  Employees are typically provided with emergency response training, on-the-job training, spill prevention and spill response training and other supplemental training.

The Facility Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of butane, procedures to inform the public about a release, and first aid and toxicity information regarding butane.  All employees working with butane are trained in handling flammable materials and are provided with annual refresher training.  A copy of this plan has been sent to the White County LEPC.  The telephone number for the LEPC is 618-384-4701.

6	Planned changes to improve safety

The procedures are reviewed annually to look for safety improvements.  The most recent PHA identified two areas for additional review.  The facility will conduct a security review to assess vulnerability due to vandalism and sabotage and potential solutions.  The PHA team also noted the possibility of vapors from a gasoline release causing a fire/explosion hazard and will ensure that training procedures address this possibility.
